from scipy import stats
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
source.6d01c78e:
fig= plt.figure()
ax1= fig.add_subplot(211)
x= stats.loggamma.rvs(5, size= 500) +5
prob = stats.probplot(x, dist= stats.norm, plot= ax1)
ax1.set_label('')
ax1.set_title('Probplot against normal distribution')


ax2= fig.add_subplot(212)
xt, _= stats.boxcox(x)
prob= stats.probplot(xt, dist= stats.norm, plot= ax2)
ax2.set_label('')
ax2.set_title('Probplot after box-cox transformation')
plt.show()

The power transformation is defined as a continuously varying function, with respect to the power parameter λ, in a piece-wise function form that makes it continuous at the point of singularity (λ = 0). For data vectors (y1,..., yn) in which each yi > 0, the power transform is

$[y_i= y_i^\lambda -1, if \lambda\neq0 ]$

$[y_i= \ln(y_i), if \lambda=0 ]$
source.a9585b66: In statistics, a power transform is a family of functions that are applied to create a monotonic transformation of data using power functions. This is a useful data transformation technique used to stabilize variance, make the data more normal distribution-like, improve the validity of measures of association such as the Pearson correlation between variables and for other data stabilization procedures.
